title: Basics Quiz
end_text:
So, are you ready to play your first game?

Looks like you scored .

As always, don't be afraid to ask questions and remember the most important non-rule of Magic: Every rule can be overwritten by something a card says.

questions.question: What is the first thing you should do at the beginning of your turn?
questions.description:
The "beginning phase" (1st phase) of each turn has 3 steps:
1) Untap
2) Upkeep
3) Draw

questions.question: What is the last step of each turn?
questions.description:
The "End Phase" has 2 steps:
1) End Step
2) Cleanup Step

questions.question: How many phases are there in a turn?
questions.description:
There are 5 phases in a turn:
1) Beginning Phase
2) Pre-combat Main Phase (1st Main Phase)
3) Combat Phase
4) Post-combat Main Phase (2nd Main Phase)
5) End Phase

questions.question: Which phase can you cast sorceries or creatures?
questions.description: Sorceries, Creatures, Enchantments, Artifacts, Planeswalkers, & Battles all are played at "Sorcery Speed" which means they can only be played during the 2 main phases on your own turn.

questions.question: Creatures with "First Strike" and/or "Double Strike" ____.

answers.text: Deal extra damage based on the number of creatures you control
Have the chance to critically hit the defending creature
Deal damage first, before most creatures

questions.description:
During combat, damage is done in 2 steps:
1) "First Strike Damage"
2) "Damage" Creatures with "Double Strike" deal damage during both steps.

questions.question: In the Standard format, what is the minimum deck size?
questions.description: In "Standard", the most common format, you need to have at least 60 cards in your deck. Though there is no maximum deck size.

questions.question: In a Commander formatted game, how many cards are allowed in a deck (including the commander)?
questions.description: A deck in the "Commander" format can only have 100 cards. This includes the commander card, which is set to the side in the "Command Zone", meaning that your library starts with only 99 cards.

questions.question: What word best describes a deck that relies heavily on a variety of card types to win the game?
questions.description:
There are 7 deck archetypes:
1) Aggressive (Aggro)
2) Control
3) Midrange
4) Combo
5) Combo-Control
6) Aggro-Control/Tempo
7) Ramp. *Check the link for more info on each*

questions.question: What word best describes a deck that focuses on slowly increasing resources to overwhelm their opponent for victory?
questions.description:
There are 7 deck archetypes:
1) Aggressive (Aggro)
2) Control
3) Midrange
4) Combo
5) Combo-Control
6) Aggro-Control/Tempo
7) Ramp *Check the link for more info on each*

questions.question: Many tournaments and events allow players to have extra cards and sometimes an extra deck. What is this called?
questions.description: A "Sideboard" is any additional cards from outside the game that can be used to modify their deck between games during a match or tournament.

questions.question: The term "CMC" stands for ____.
questions.description: "CMC" stands for "Converted Mana Cost", which is simply the total number of mana needed to cast a spell. CMC ignores what color of mana is used and any additional, optional costs (like "Kicker")

questions.question: Creatures have two numbers "##/##". Which term does the first number mean?
questions.description: The 2 numbers every creature has stand for their Power and Toughness. This is always seen as "Power/Toughness" with the slash inbetween.

questions.question: Creatures have two numbers "##/##". Which term does the second number mean?
questions.description: The 2 numbers every creature has stand for their Power and Toughness. This is always seen as "Power/Toughness" with the slash inbetween.

questions.question: What ability is commonly associated only with creature cards?
questions.description: While all of these are keywords and you may find all of them on a creature at some point, only "Flying" is exclusively seen on creatures. The others are often also seen on the other card types such as Artifacts and Enchantments.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a card type
questions.description: "Clash" is a keyword rather than a card type. Though, it might sound similar to a less-common type, "Battle"

questions.question: What is a common strategy to maintain a balanced mana base in a deck?

answers.text: Maximize only one type of land

questions.description: Even if your deck has 95% of one color and only 5% of a different, you should still diversify your land types, giving you a better chance to have the second color when you actually need it. Most cards will only have 1 or 2 of a single color in its mana cost, the rest being grey, or colorless, mana that any color can be used for.

questions.question: What is the best way to improve at playing?

answers.text: Always play with a similar deck
Make up interpretations of the rules
Bring snacks so your opponents like you more

questions.description: Obviously, simply playing more will give you more experience. But, to improve quicker, you should never be afraid to ask questions and learn from more experienced players. Especially in the casual setting most games (outside of tournaments) are played with, most people are happy to help.

questions.question: What is a common mistake new players tend to make?

answers.text: Focusing on the cards' flavor text

questions.description: You should always ask questions, especially the "Why" questions. Why did you win/lose? Why did they win? What could you have done differently? How can you recognise that in the future?

questions.question: What concept should be heavily considered when building a deck?
questions.description: "Synergy" is how well cards work with each other. Are there a lot of cards in the deck that work well with each other? Do these cards work well in a variety of combinations? The website edhrec.com/combos lists a lot of (definitely not all) combos that can get you started.

questions.question: The "Library" refers to ____.

answers.text: The deck of cards you draw from
The place where cards are stored for later use after casting
The cards you've played on the table

questions.description: The "Library" is the stack of cards from your deck that haven't been played or drawn yet. Though sometimes (such as with "Mill"), cards might leave your library without having been played or drawn.
